questions.text: Which of the following is true about the type of fixation shown in the image?

options.label: D
options.text: Periarticular fracture of knee, spanning fixator

questions.correct_answer: D. Periarticular fracture of knee, spanning fixator
questions.explanation:
Definition

A type of external fixation device used to stabilize fractures or deformities, spanning over a joint.

Indications
  • Complex fractures
  • Joint instability
  • Bone deformities
  • Temporary stabilization during healing

Types
  • Unilateral fixator
  • Bilateral fixator
  • Circular fixator

Mechanism of Action

The fixator applies external support to immobilize the fractured area and maintain proper alignment while healing.

Advantages
  • Minimizes surgical exposure
  • Adjustable design
  • Can be used in complex fractures
  • Can be applied to both long bones and joints

Disadvantages
  • Pin-site infections
  • Risk of soft tissue damage
  • Aesthetic concerns due to external frame

Duration of Use

Typically used temporarily, but can be extended depending on the severity of the fracture or injury.

questions.text: A male patient presented with the fracture of Tibia following a road traffic accident. He was managed appropriately, but after 2 days he developed dyspnea, petechiae involving the whole body, and a fall in oxygen saturation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A) Fat Embolism

Major criteria

Minor criteria
  • Respiratory insufficiency (symptoms and radiologic evidence)
  • Cerebral dysfunction not caused by head injury or other conditions
  • Petechial rash
  • Tachycardia (>110 beats/min)
  • Pyrexia (temperature >38.5°C)
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal dysfunction
  • Jaundice
  • Acute drop in haemoglobin
  • Sudden thrombocytopenia
  • Elevated ESR
  • Fat macroglobulinemia.

questions.text: An intrauterine scan at the 13th week of pregnancy showed a fetus with multiple long bone fractures. What is commonly associated with this finding?
What is the most common Late complication of this condition, if left untreated ?
questions.explanation:
Supracondylar Fractures

Mechanism of injury

Fall on outstretched hand (FOOSH)

Location

Humerus fractures just above the condyles.

Displacements

The distal fragment of the humerus is usually displaced by

  • Posterior shift (Due to Impaction)
  • Posterior Tilt
  • Proximal shift
  • Medial shift/ Tilt
  • Internal rotation

Types
  • Type 1: Undisplaced fracture
  • Type 2: Partially displaced fracture with displacement of only anterior cortex
  • Type 3: Completely displaced anterior and posterior cortex.

Clinical Presentation
  • Severe elbow pain, swelling, deformity, and loss of function may occur, and neurological symptoms like weakness in wrist flexion or the "hand of benediction" sign may also occur if the median nerve is affected.
  • Unusual posterior prominence of the olecranon in the backward tilt (S-shaped deformity)
  • The skin around the fracture has a dimpled appearance (Dimple sign)

X-ray Findings
  • Three bony parts relationship is maintained.
  • Fat Pad or Sail sign: A translucent shadow-like appearance representing anterior and posterior fat pads.
  • Disturbed tear drop sign: An abnormal appearance of the fat pad, suggesting the presence of an injury, such as a fracture or joint effusion.

 

  • Fishtail sign: The ends of the proximal fragment are slightly widened and serrated, resembling a fishtail.

 

  • Crescent sign: The normal radiolucent gap of the elbow joint is replaced by a crescent-shaped shadow from the capitulum overlapping the olecranon, indicating varus or valgus tilt of the distal fragment.

Management

Based on the type of fracture

  • Undisplaced fracture: Immobilisation in above-elbow plaster slab with the elbow in 90-degree flexion.
  • Displaced fractures
    • Closed reduction with percutaneous K-wire fixation. (for Type 2 fracture)
    • Open reduction internal fixation with K-wire. (for Type 3 fracture)
  • In Late presentation with swelling
    • Dunlop traction (skin)
    • Smith traction (skeletal)

Complications
  • Early complications
    • Vascular injury (commonly Brachial artery)
    • Nerve injury (commonly Anterior Interosseous nerve)
  • Delayed complications
    • Cubitus varus or Gunstock deformity (Malunion) (Option C)
    • Volkmann's Ischemia and compartment syndrome.
    • Elbow stiffness
    • Myositis ossificans.

questions.text: A child with a history of recurrent respiratory infections presented with complaints of pain around the knee along with high fever. X – ray shows lytic and sclerotic bone. His peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. The organism most likely involved is?

A boy falls on the left shoulder joint and presents to the emergency department with shoulder pain. His left elbow is flexed and is supported by the right hand. Which bone might be most likely fractured?
DNA packing is done by which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Core Histones: H2A, H2B, H3, and H4

Linker Histone: H1
  • These histones are highly conserved across species, indicating their essential role in cellular processes.
  • The core histones form the nucleosome by creating a histone octamer around which DNA is wrapped.
  • The carboxyl-terminal two-thirds of the histone molecules are hydrophobic, while the amino-terminal thirds are rich in basic amino acids.

 
  • H1 is the least tightly bound to chromatin and can be easily removed with a salt solution, making chromatin more soluble.
  • H1 interacts with DNA as it enters and exits the nucleosome, playing a role in the higher-order structure of chromatin.

 

Histone Octamer

The histone octamer is the fundamental unit of the nucleosome and consists of eight histone molecules:

  • Two molecules each of H2A, H2B, H3, and H4.
  • These histones interact specifically to form a structure with the composition (H3–H4)₂–(H2A–H2B)₂.
  • H3 and H4 form a tetramer (H3–H4)₂, and H2A and H2B form dimers (H2A–H2B).
  • This octamer binds approximately 145-150 base pairs of DNA, creating 1.75 superhelical turns around it.

questions.text: Which of the options aids in the transportation of fatty acids through the inner mitochondria membrane?
What is the term for a single mutation in a nucleotide base pair that leads to formation of termination codon?
questions.explanation:
Based on the Effects on Amino acid sequence

Silent Mutation (Option D)

Missense Mutation (Option A)

Nonsense Mutation (Option B)
  • Mutation may change the codon for one amino acid to a synonym for the same amino acid.
  • It has no effect on the phenotype.
  • Degeneracy of the code.
  • Different amino acid is incorporated due to change in the nucleotide sequence.
  • It can be acceptable, partially acceptable, and unacceptable.
  • Codon for an amino acid is mutated to a termination codon (UAA or UGA or UAG) causing premature termination of translation.

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines with which strain could have prevented it?
questions.explanation:
Yellow fever

Agent and Vector
  • Flavivirus transmitted primarily by mosquitoes
    • Aedes Mosquito (in urban settings)
    • Haemagogus (in jungle or forested areas)

Hosts
  • Primarily monkeys (Reservoir hosts)
  • Humans are (Incidental hosts) and can develop severe disease.

Environmental Features
  • Found in tropical and subtropical areas of Africa and South America, where mosquito vectors are prevalent.
  • Transmission occurs primarily in forested or jungle areas.
  • Typical Conditions:
  • Temperature: 24-36’C
  • Humidity: >60%

Clinical Presentation
  • Initial symptoms (acute phase, 3-6 days post-infection): fever, chills, headache, backache, muscle aches, loss of appetite.
  • Severe cases (toxic phase): jaundice, bleeding, organ dysfunction (liver, kidney).

Diagnosis
  • Based on clinical signs
  • Travel history to endemic areas
  • Confirmed by detection of YFV RNA or specific antibodies (IgM and IgG) in blood samples.

Types
  • Live-attenuated vaccine (17D strain)
  • Diluent: lyophilized (freeze-dried) powder with saline solution.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Symptoms

 
  • Hearing Loss: Conductive, mild to moderate (20-40 dB), gradual onset, may fluctuate; children may not complain, but parents may notice difficulties in hearing.
  • Delayed/Defective Speech
  • Mild Earaches
  • Fullness in Ear.

Signs

 
  • Tympanic Membrane Appearance: Dull, opaque, possibly yellow, grey, or bluish; absence of the usual light reflex.
  • Visible Fluid/Bubbles: Air-fluid levels or bubbles visible behind the eardrum.
  • Retracted Tympanic Membrane: Negative middle ear pressure causing eardrum retraction, with the malleus handle appearing shortened or horizontal.
  • Reduced Tympanic Membrane Mobility.

Test

Description

Rinne Test
  • In conductive hearing loss (SOM), bone conduction is better than air conduction (negative Rinne test).

Weber Test
  • In conductive hearing loss (SOM), the sound is louder in the affected ear when the tuning fork is placed on the forehead.

Absolute Bone Conduction (ABC) Test
  • Both patient and examiner hear the tuning fork for a similar duration when placed on the mastoid bone (ear canals plugged) in conductive hearing loss (SOM). (Bone conduction not impaired)

Schwabach's Test
  • In conductive hearing loss (SOM), the patient hears the tuning fork for a longer duration than the examiner when placed on the mastoid bone (ear canals not plugged).

Pneumatic Otoscopy
  • Visualizes eardrum movement with air pressure changes; reduced/absent movement indicates fluid presence.

Impedance audiometry
  • Measures eardrum movement; typically shows a flat/dome-shaped curve with negative pressure, indicating reduced compliance.

Audiometry
  • Conductive hearing loss (20-40 dB).
  • Sometimes, associated sensorineural hearing loss (d/t fluid on the round window membrane.

X-ray/CT Scan of Temporal Bone
  • May show mastoid air cell clouding due to fluid

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a known case of hypertension presented with multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain. His elder brother passed away due to a stroke at the age of 40. The CT abdomen is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: B. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
questions.explanation:
Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

Definition

Characterised by the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys.

Inheritance
  • Autosomal Dominant
  • Involvement of chromosome 16 (PKD1) and 4 (PKD2)
  • Abnormal protein-Polycystin
  • Both kidneys are replaced by multiple cysts

Clinical Features (Intrarenal)
  • Most common manifestation is hypertension
  • Polyuria, Nocturia, Hematuria
  • Nephrolithiasis
  • Chronic renal failure (Usually in the 5th to 6th decade)
  • Any compression in the pelvicalyceal system will lead to HIS (Hydronephrosis; Infection; Stone) → Hematuria

Clinical Features (Extrarenal)
  • Polycystic Liver Disease (Most common)
  • Cyst in Ovary, Pancreas, Spleen Berry Aneurysm
  • Mitral Valve prolapse
  • The most common cause of death is cardiovascular Disorders

Investigations
  • Investigation of choice: CECT
  • Ultrasound: Confirms the presence of cysts
  • IVP (Intravenous Pyelogram):
    • Spider leg/Bell-shaped appearance
    • Bubble appearance
    • Swiss-cheese appearance
  • Blood urea and serum creatinine: Elevated
  • Urine: Shows low specific gravity

Management
  • Wait and watch initially. Surgical intervention is required only after cysts get overdistended, causing pain, hemorrhage, and infection.
  • Gold Standard: Renal Transplantation
  • Rovsing's Operation: Deroofing of Cyst in ADPKD. The kidney is exposed. The cyst is opened. The fluid is evacuated.
  • US-guided aspiration & Laparoscopic aspiration is commonly done as a simpler approach.
  • Once renal failure sets in, initial hemodialysis followed by bilateral nephrectomy is done, and later renal transplantation can be planned

questions.text: A militant presents with fever and a rash that started on the trunk first and spread to the extremities, sparing palms and soles. On examination, a louse is noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Epidemic typhus

Causative agent

Rickettsia prowazekii (It is the only rickettsial disease that can occur as an epidemic)

Vector

Louse

Pathophysiology
  • It occurs during conditions favourable to human body lice infestation such as in refugee and famine camps.(crowding, infrequent bathing)
  • The cycle starts with R.prowazekii circulating in a patient’s blood during an acute febrile infection.
  • After 5 to 10 days of incubation, large numbers of rickettsiae appear in its infective faeces.
  • Since the louse defecates when it feeds, the organisms can be rubbed into the louse bite wounds when the host scratches the site.
  • Dried louse faeces are also infectious through the mucous membranes of the eye or respiratory tract. The louse dies of its infection in 1 to 3 weeks.
  • Most of Rickettsiae, including Rickettsia prowazekii, shows tropism for vascular endothelium.
  • They multiply in the endothelial cells, leading to increased vascular permeability, hypovolemia, and hypotension.
  • Focal areas of endothelial proliferation cause the rash and petechial lesions, perivascular infiltration that leads to thrombosis, and leakage of red blood cells into the surrounding tissues.

Clinical features

  • Fever, headache, and rash begin 1 to 2 weeks after the bite.
  • In the majority of cases, a maculopapular rash appears first on the trunk and then spreads centrifugally to the extremities, sparing the palms and soles.
  • Eschar is absent at the site of entry.
  • Headache, malaise, and myalgia are prominent components of the illness.
  • Complications include myocarditis and central nervous system dysfunction.
  • In untreated disease, the fatality rate increases with age as much as 60%.

Investigations

  • The diagnostic test of choice is serology i.e. rise in antibody titre.
  • Weil-Felix test showing both OX 19+ and OX 2+.

Treatment

  • Treatment with doxycycline is effective.
  • Louse control is the best means of prevention and is particularly important in controlling epidemics.
  • No effective vaccine is available.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man complained of recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for 3 years. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Fistula in ano

Causes
  • Idiopathic/Cryptoglandular: The most common cause, often associated with prior anorectal sepsis.
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Crohn’s disease
    • Tuberculosis
    • Lymphogranuloma venereum
    • Actinomycosis
    • Rectal duplication
    • Foreign bodies
    • Malignancy (rare, can develop within a longstanding fistula)

Clinical features
  • Intermittent purulent discharge: This may be bloody and purulent. Discomfort typically increases until the pus discharges, providing temporary relief.
  • Previous history of Anorectal abscess
  • Passage of flatus or faeces: Through the external opening (indicative of a rectal rather than an anal internal opening).

questions.text: A 60-year-old post-COVID male patient came with complaints of one-sided facial swelling, headache, and nasal sinus congestion. He is diabetic and it is uncontrolled. On examination black lesions on the nasal bridge and upper inside of the mouth were observed. Which investigation would you do to confirm the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Mucormycosis

Description

A severe fungal infection primarily affects the nose and sinuses but can quickly spread to the orbit, cribriform plate, meninges, and brain. The fungus invades arteries, causing endothelial damage, thrombosis, and rapid tissue destruction.

Characteristic Findings

Black necrotic material in the nasal cavity, eroding the nasal septum, hard palate, and turbinates. Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast enhanced MRI.

Risk Factors
  • Uncontrolled diabetes, especially with ketoacidosis
  • Prolonged steroid use (common in COVID-19 treatment)
  • Conditions causing immunosuppression: Neutropenia, HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy, organ transplants, and kidney issues.

Diagnosis
  • Endoscopy: Shows pale mucosa early, progressing to black crusts and sloughing.
  • Biopsy: Multiple sites should be sampled for fungal identification; potassium hydroxide preparation is the gold standard for confirming invasive features.

Imaging
  • CT: Detects bony destruction and initial assessment of sinus involvement.
  • CECT: CECT provides better delineation of soft tissue structures, allowing for clearer identification of mucosal thickening, sinus opacification, and bony destruction.
  • MRI: Evaluates soft tissue invasion, assesses the extent of extra-sinus disease, and identifies complications, especially in the orbit and brain.

Treatment

Antifungal Therapy:

  • Amphotericin B: 0.6 to 1 mg/kg/day IV or liposomal Amphotericin B: 5 mg/kg/day.
  • Posaconazole: 300 mg twice daily orally on the first day, then 300 mg once daily.

Surgical Intervention:

  • Endoscopic debridement of necrotic tissues.
  • Severe cases: Total/Partial maxillectomy or orbital exenteration may be required.

questions.explanation: Correct Option A) Facial nerv

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with right upper quadrant pain, calf pain, conjunctival suffusion, icterus, and fever. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Leptospirosis

Agent
  • Leptospira interrogans (zoonotic bacteria)

Reservoir
  • Rodents (Ratus norvegicus, Mus musculus) and domestic animals

Source
  • Direct contact or contamination with excreta, urine of infected animals.

At risk individuals
  • Males 20-45 years (most common)
  • Urine-contaminated mud(Soil) or water
    • Sports: rafting, fishing and swimming
    • Rice field workers, sewer workers, animal handlers

Mode of transmission
  • Direct contact: Urine through skin abrasion
  • Indirect contact: Contact of broken skin with soil, water, vegetation
  • Droplet infection: Inhalation while milking cows.

Incubation
  • 4-20 days

Clinical features:
  • Fever with chills
  • Headache & retro-orbital pain
  • Conjunctival suffusion
  • Myalgia
  • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea
  • Non-specific rash

 

  • Anicteric leptospirosis:
  • Milder form
  • Pulmonary manifestations are primary concern
  • Icteric leptospirosis:
  • More severe form
  • Jaundice, fever, myalgia hypotension,
  • Circulatory failure

Diagnosis
  • Dark Field examination: Thin and motile spirochete.
  • IgM ELISA: High sensitivity
  • Labs: Elevated liver enzymes, increased bilirubin, thrombocytopenia

questions.text: A newly joined teacher develops rice-water stools. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors?

A patient with cisplatin-induced nausea and vomiting was managed with an antiemetic, after which he developed symptoms like acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. Which of the following drugs would have caused these symptoms?
Which of the following is considered to be the best for the detection of Clostridium difficile?
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis

Colonoscopy
  • Examination of the colon whitish-yellow plaques on the colonic mucosa known as microabscesses.
  • Although it is highly specific, it is not as sensitive as ELISA, hence it is not considered the Gold standard for diagnosis. (Option D ruled out)

 

Culture
  • Stool samples cultured on selective media to identify C. difficile; less sensitive than toxin detection. (Option A ruled out)

Toxin Detection
  • ELISA: Detects toxins A and/or B in stool samples, the gold standard (Option B).
  • Cell Culture: Toxins produce characteristic effects on Hep-2 or human diploid cell cultures, neutralized by C. sordellii antitoxin.

Molecular Methods
  • PCR: Detects genes coding for toxins A and B in stool samples.

Histopathology
  • This can be performed with hematoxylin and eosin stains
  • Highly specific but low sensitivity

Treatment

Antibiotic Discontinuation
  • Stop the antibiotic suspected of contributing to the infection.

Antibiotic Therapy
  • Oral vancomycin or metronidazole.
  • Severe cases: Combination of oral vancomycin, intravenous metronidazole, and rectal vancomycin enemas.

Prevention

Antibiotic Stewardship
  • Limit the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics like clindamycin, ampicillin, and fluoroquinolones; prevent disruption of normal gut flora.

Infection Control Measures
  • Meticulous hand hygiene and contact precautions in healthcare settings.

Recent Treatment Option

Fecal Transplants
  • Replenishing gut flora with donated faeces from screened healthy donor

questions.text: A truck driver with diabetes visits you complaining of cough and difficulty breathing. Pneumonia has been diagnosed, and histopathological examination indicates the presence of nonseptate hyphae branching at wide angles. What is the probable cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Mucormycosis

It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

Rhizopus

Absidia Mucor (Lactophenol cotton blue stained)

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

Common Sites

  • Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.
  • Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.
  • Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

 

Clinical Features
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:
    • Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.
    • Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.
  • Pulmonary Zygomycosis:
    • Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

Culture:

  • After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.
  • Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

​​​​​​a. ​

b.

a. Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

b. Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:
  • Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.
  • Medical control of diabetes is required.

questions.text: A woman who was prescribed a broad-spectrum antibiotic presents with recurrent diarrhea. Regarding Clostridium difficile infection, which of the following statements is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment

options.label: D
options.text: Pseudomembrane is a layer of inflammatory cells and debris

questions.correct_answer: C. No risk of fulminant infection
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Inflammatory condition of the colon caused by Clostridium difficile toxin production, leading to pseudomembrane formation on the colonic mucosa.

Etiology
  • Primarily caused by C. difficile infection, usually after broad-spectrum antibiotic use (e.g., clindamycin, fluoroquinolones, cephalosporins).

Risk Factors
  • Recent antibiotic use
  • Hospitalization
  • Elderly patients
  • Immunosuppression (e.g., chemotherapy, organ transplant)
  • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs)

Pathogenesis
  • C. difficile produces Toxin A (enterotoxin) and Toxin B (cytotoxin), leading to mucosal damage, inflammation, and pseudomembrane formation.

Clinical Features
  • Watery diarrhea (non-bloody)
  • Abdominal pain and cramping
  • Fever
  • Leukocytosis
  • Severe cases: Toxic megacolon, perforation, septic shock

Endoscopic Findings
  • Yellow-white plaques on the colonic mucosa (pseudomembranes)
  • Patchy or confluent distribution

Diagnosis
  • Stool toxin assay (Toxin A & B ELISA or PCR) - Gold standard.
  • Glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH) assay
  • Colonoscopy/Sigmoidoscopy

Treatment
  • First-line: Oral vancomycin or fidaxomicin
  • Alternative: Oral metronidazole
  • Severe/Recurrent cases: Fecal microbiota transplantation

Complications
  • Fulminant colitis
  • Toxic megacolon
  • Intestinal perforation
  • Sepsis & Multi-organ failure

questions.text: An adult man in a restaurant suddenly begins choking on his food. He is conscious. The following procedure was performed. Identify the procedure.

A young patient started to take a weight loss medication that acts by inhibiting fat absorption from food. After a few weeks, she developed increased menstrual bleeding and stool that sticks to the pan. Which of the following vitamins is responsible for her deficiency?

A diabetic patient presented with rhinitis and facial swelling. An intranasal biopsy revealed the presence of broad-based aseptate hyphae with branching at the right angle. Evidence of vascular invasion was present. What will be the drug of choice
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Amphotericin B

Mechanism of Action

Binds to ergosterol in fungal cell membranes, forming pores that disrupt membrane integrity, leading to leakage of cellular contents and fungal cell death.

Preparation
  • Conventional Amphotericin B (c-AMB)
  • Amphotericin B lipid complex (ABLC)
  • Liposomal Amphotericin B (L-AMB)

Use

Cryptococcal meningitis, mucormycosis, coccidioidal meningitis.

Adverse Effects
  • Nephrotoxicity: Most notable with conventional Amphotericin B (c-AMB); less with liposomal formulations
  • Fever, chills, and hypotension can be managed with pre-treatment (NSAIDs, antihistamines)
  • Anaemia (requires erythropoietin treatment)
  • Renal tubular acidosis leads to electrolyte imbalances (hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia)
  • Arachnoiditis, when used intrathecally

  • ➤ Adenosine A1 receptors are found in the kidneys and are involved in regulating water and electrolyte balance. By blocking adenosine A1 receptors, theophylline can lead to increased urine production and diuresis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not likely to cause Pulmonary fibrosis?
questions.explanation:
Side effects and complications of Metformin


 

Side effects
  • Nausea/Vomiting/Diarrhoea
  • Megaloblastic anaemia: reduces vitamin B12 absorption from GIT
  • Lactic acidosis
    • Avoid metformin in COPD, CHF, dehydration, and sepsis (hypoxia increases lactic acid production).









 

Complications
  • Renal failure is common with metformin use.
  • Plasma metformin levels are inversely related to GFR due to reduced drug clearance.
  • Current guidelines suggest the safe use of metformin when GFR is more than 30 mL/min/1.73 m2.
  • Management:
    • Assess renal function before starting metformin and monitor it annually.
    • Discontinue if serum creatinine >1.5 mg/dL or eGFR < 30 mL/min/1.73 m2.
    • Discontinue pre-emptively before radiographic procedures using contrast dyes (till 48 hours after the procedure until renal function normalises) and hospitalization for severe illness (sepsis).
    • Dose adjustment is needed for cationic drugs excreted by renal tubular secretion, such as cimetidine, furosemide, nifedipine, etc.
    • It is indicated in patients with severe pulmonary disease, heart failure, liver disease, or chronic alcohol abuse.

questions.text: According to biomedical waste management protocols, what is the proper method of disposing of a broken vaccine vial?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Puncture proof blu

Color

Type of waste

Example of waste

Treatment and disposal

Yellow
  • Human anatomical waste.
  • Animal anatomical waste.
  • Soiled waste.
  • Discarded or expired medicine.
  • Microbiology, biotechnology and other clinical laboratory waste.
  • Chemical waste.
  • Chemical liquid waste.

 
  • Placenta.
  • Post-operative body parts.
  • Plaster of Paris (POP).
  • Pathological waste.
  • Cotton waste.
  • Dressing materials.
  • Beddings.
  • Body fluid contaminated paper and cloth.
  • Face mask, cap, shoe cover and head cover.
  • Cytotoxic, expired and discarded medicines.
  • Microbiology and biotechnology lab waste.
  • Blood bag
  • Vacutainers with blood
  • Incineration.
  • Plasma pyrolysis.
  • Deep burial.

 

Red
  • Contaminated waste that is recyclable.
  • Syringe without needles.
  • Fixed needle syringes with their needle cut.
  • IV set.
  • Catheters.
  • Gloves (soiled or unsoiled).
  • Urine bag.
  • Dialysis kit.
  • IV bottles.
  • Tubing's.
  • Bottles.
  • Vacutainers with needle cuts.
  • Vacutainers without blood.
  • ELISA plates and vials not containing blood samples.
  • Autoclaving or microwaving/ hydroclaving followed by shredding or mutilation and waste set to registered recyclers or for energy recovery/road making.
  • Plastic waste should not be sent to landfill sites.

White

Waste Sharps
  • Needles
  • Syringes with fixed needles
  • Blades
  • Scalpers
  • Trocar cannula
  • Insulin pen needle

 
  • Puncture proof , Leak proof, Tamper proof containers
  • Autoclaving or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding or mutilation or encapsulation in metal container or cement concrete
  • Or sent for final disposal to iron foundries or sanitary landfills or designated concrete waste sharp pit

 

Blue

Glassware or metallic body implants.
  • Includes broken or discarded glass and metallic objects that are contaminated.
  • Glass:
    • Broken glass.
    • Ampoules.
    • Lab slide
  • Metals:
    • Nails.
    • Metallic body implants.
    • Scissors.
    • Artificial pacemakers.

 
  • Cardboard boxes with blue colored markings or blue coloured puncture-proof and tamper-proof containers.
  • Disinfection (cleaning with detergent and soaking in sodium hypochlorite) or autoclaving or microwaving or hydroclaving and then sent for recycling.

questions.text: Identify the fluid shown below on the basis of composition: Sodium (Na+) 131 millimoles per liter Chloride (Cl-) 111 millimoles per liter Lactate 29 millimoles per liter Potassium (K+) 5 millimoles per liter Calcium (Ca2+) 2 millimoles per liter Total osmolarity 279 millimoles per liter
What is the probable diagnosis for an elderly male patient who experienced scrotal pain and discharge, as indicated in the provided image?
questions.explanation:
Fournier's Gangrene

Definition

Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through five phases:
    • Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy.
    • Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible edema, pruritus.
    • Progressive Phase: Increased pain and erythema.
    • Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation.
    • Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge.
  • Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses.
  • Severity ranges from localised tenderness to septic shock.

Risk Factors

Peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, alcoholism, immunocompromised states.

Diagnosis

Clinical presentation supported by imaging or lab findings.

Management
  • Initial Treatment:
    • Fluid resuscitation.
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue.
  • Additional Measures:
    • Urinary and fecal diversion to prevent wound contamination.
    • Intensive monitoring for sepsis.
    • Wound review and vacuum-assisted dressing.
    • Skin grafting post-infection control.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with a history of consumption of 8 tablets of digoxin. On examination, he was unstable, and his heart rate was 56 bpm. ECG showed a 3rd-degree heart block. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Digoxin

Mechanism of action of digoxin

Direct action

Indirect action

Digoxin ⟶ Inhibition of Na⁺-K⁺ATPase Pump ⟶ Intracellular Na⁺ Accumulation ⟶ Intracellular Ca²⁺ Increase ⟶ Enhanced Myocardial Contractility ⟶ Positive Inotropic Effect ⟶ Increased Cardiac Output ⟶ Treatment of Heart Failure

Vagotonic effect ⟶ Increased parasympathetic/vagal tone ⟶ Blocking both S.A and A.V node ⟶ Prolongation of Refractory Period ⟶ Slowing of Conduction Through AV Node ⟶ Control of Rate in Arrhythmias

Signs and symptoms of Digoxin toxicity:

Arrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia)

Hyperkalemia

Hypokalemia

Bradycardia

Neurological symptoms (e.g., confusion, delirium)

ECG Changes with Digoxin
  • ↑ PR Interval → AV node block
  • ↑ RR Interval → SA node block
  • Narrow QRS→ Tells about Ventricular depolarisation - ↑ intracellular sodium
  • Inverted T wave→↓ intracellular potassium
  • Reverse tick sign/ Salvador Dali sign - Characteristic of digoxin toxicity

Antidote

Digoxin-specific antibody fragments (Digibind)

Vessels involved and common sites of obstruction (in Atherosclerosis)

Vessel

Common Sites of Obstruction

Related Manifestations/Findings

Aorta

Infrarenal aorta

Bilateral lower limb ischemia, absent femoral pulses

Iliac arteries

Common iliac bifurcation
  • Unilateral lower limb ischemia, absent femoral pulse.
  • Pain in the buttock is due to a block in the common iliac or aortoiliac segment (30%), often associated with impotence and is called Leriche's syndrome.

Femoral artery

(Option D ruled out)

Common femoral artery

Calf claudication, absent popliteal and distal pulses

Popliteal artery

(Option A ruled out)

Adductor canal

Calf and foot ischemia, absent pedal pulses

Tibial arteries

Proximal or mid-calf

Foot ischemia, absent pedal pulses

Subclavian artery

Proximal subclavian

Arm ischemia, absent radial/ulnar pulses.

Subclavian steal syndrome:

Obstruction of the first part of the subclavian artery can cause reverse blood flow through the vertebral artery, providing collateral circulation to the arm but affecting the posterior brain and upper limb, with steal being occult, partial, or complete.

Brachial artery

Mid-humerus level

Forearm and hand ischemia, absent radial/ulnar pulses

questions.explanation:
Aspect

True Aneurysm

False (Pseudoaneurysm)

Definition

Involves all three layers of the arterial wall.

Involves only a layer of fibrous tissue outside the vessel.

Wall Structure

Intima, media, and adventitia are involved.

Only fibrous tissue surrounds the breach.

Morphology

Fusiform or saccular.

Typically spherical or ovoid.

Aetiology

Atherosclerosis, genetic conditions.

Trauma, surgery, or arterial puncture.

Clinical Features

May be asymptomatic until complications arise.

Often presents with a pulsatile mass or pain.

Common Locations

Large arteries (e.g., aorta, iliac).

Peripheral arteries (e.g., femoral, popliteal).

Diagnosis

Detected by ultrasound, CT, and MRI.

Detected by ultrasound or angiography.

Management

Surgical repair or endovascular techniques.

Repair or percutaneous methods (e.g., thrombin injection).

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient who is a chronic alcoholic presents with oral ulcers and a burning sensation. A picture of the oral cavity is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Leukoplakia

Definition

White patch on oral mucosa, defined clinically, excluding conditions like lichen planus, candidiasis, etc.

Causes
  • Smoking, tobacco chewing
  • Alcohol abuse (especially with smoking)
  • Chronic trauma (ill-fitting dentures, cheek bites)
  • Associated with submucous fibrosis, hyperplastic candidiasis, Plummer-Vinson syndrome

Common sites
  • Buccal mucosa (most common in India)
  • Oral commissures, floor of mouth, tongue, gingivobuccal sulcus, lip mucosa

Age & Gender
  • Men in their 40s are 2-3 times more affected than females.

Clinical types
  • Homogenous: Smooth or wrinkled white patch, lower malignancy risk
  • Nodular (speckled): White patches on an erythematous base, higher malignancy risk
  • Erosive (erythroleukoplakia): Interspersed with red patches, fissures, highest malignancy risk

Malignant potential
  • 1-17.5% risk, average 5% malignant transformation
  • Higher risk in dysplastic lesions and certain locations

Treatment
  • Remove causative factors: Spontaneous regression in some cases.
  • Biopsy: For lesions with high malignant potential.
  • Surgical excision or laser/cryotherapy: For suspicious or small lesions

questions.explanation:
Vesicoureteric reflux

Causes
  • Congenital: Commonly associated with posterior urethral valve
  • Acquired: Trauma due to surgery or intervention

Clinical Features
  • Recurrent UTI and Pyelonephritis
  • Palpable mass in the loin
  • Renal failure in bilateral cases

Complications
  • Renal scarring, if not managed in symptomatic patients

Investigations
  • Micturating cystourethrogram (IOC)
  • Intravenous urography
  • Urine microscopy and C/S
  • Blood urea and serum creatinine

Treatment

Grade I to III- Antibiotic Prophylaxis as it resolves spontaneously in most patients.

Grade IV to V- Antibiotics + Surgery

Only symptomatic patients require surgical correction via ureteric reimplantation.

Surgery:

  • Ureterovesicoplasty
  • Ureteric reimplantation (Lich-Gregoir technique)
  • STING Operation (Endoscopic)

Severe cases may require nephrectomy and renal transplantation.

questions.text: A young male patient with a history of a motor vehicle accident cannot pass urine. Blood is seen at the meatus. What is the most likely site of urethral injury?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Membranous urethra

Location

Membranous urethra (bulbomembranous junction most common)

Common Causes
  • Pelvic fractures (often due to motor vehicle accidents)
  • Blunt trauma

Clinical Features
  • Blood at the meatus
  • Inability to void
  • High-riding prostate on rectal exam
  • Perineal or suprapubic pain
  • Pelvic hematoma associated with pelvic fractures
  • Possible concomitant bladder injury

Investigations
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard for initial assessment
  • CT Urethrography: Useful in evaluating complex injuries
  • Pelvic CT Scan: Important for associated pelvic fractures
  • Cystoscopy: Sometimes performed for further evaluation

questions.text: A delayed intravenous urogram of a patient is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Pelviureteric junction obstruction

Causes
  • Congenital
    • Atresia/stenosis - Developmental anomaly that leads to an intrinsic narrowing
    • Aberrant left renal artery - The presence of an abnormal blood vessel compressing the junction externally
  • Acquired
    • Scarring from previous infections
    • Kidney stones (most common)
    • Surgery - stricture formation

Clinical Features
  • Intermittent Flank Pain - increased fluid intake or diuresis, which increases urine production and pressure at the obstruction site.
  • Hematuria - if there are associated kidney stones.
  • Recurrent Urinary Tract Infections
  • Hydronephrosis - may be asymptomatic in the early stages.

Investigations
  • Ultrasound
  • Diuretic Renal Scan (DTPA Scan) - Investigation of choice
  • Whittaker’s Test: This is an invasive pressure-flow study used if the DTPA Scan is equivocal, to differentiate between true obstruction and non-obstructive hydronephrosis by measuring the pressure gradient across the PUJ.
  • Magnetic Resonance Urography (MRU): Helps to pinpoint the location and cause of the obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK9 inhibitor?

A 45-year-old patient complained of pain in one side of the neck. She is afraid of eating food as it worsens the pain. Ultrasound imaging of the salivary glands is done and shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Osteoma of the floor of the mouth

questions.explanation:
Sialolithiasis

Definition

Formation of salivary gland stones within the gland ducts

Commonly Affected Age

30 to 60 years

Commonly Affected Gland

Submandibular gland (85%), due to its ascending duct course and the mucinous, viscous saliva it produces, leads to stagnation and stone formation.

Risk Factors
  • Duct abnormalities
  • Inflammation
  • Increased calcium content in saliva
  • Chronic dehydration
  • Medications causing decreased salivary flow

Clinical Features

Cyclical postprandial swelling, dryness, asymmetrical gland enlargement, palpable stone, possible abscess formation.

 

Submandibular Swelling

Diagnostic Methods
  • Conventional Radiographs: Initial diagnostic test, but may miss small stones.
  • CT Scanning, USG, Magnetic Resonance Sialogram: More sensitive, especially for small stones.
  • Sialography: Gold standard; involves dye injection for diagnosis and potential therapeutic use.
  • Sialendoscopy: Direct visualization and removal of stones, safer than open surgery.

CT- Wharton’s duct Sialolithiasis

Treatment Options
  • Small Distal Stones (<5 mm): Endoscopic removal
  • Large Distal Stones (>5 mm): Duct slitting
  • Impacted Stones: Transoral route
  • Intraparenchymal Stones (5–7 mm): Endoscopic extraction
  • Large Stones (7-10 mm): May require transoral slitting or external shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL)
  • Hilar Stones: Endoscopic removal
  • Gland Removal: Last resort if other treatments fail

questions.text: An elderly man presents with rigidity and tremors. On examination, he has blank facial expressions. Which of the following drugs can be used to manage this?
A patient presented with a 0.3 cm nodule on the left nasolabial fold. It was excised, and a pathological examination was done. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Basal cell carcinoma
  • Also known as Rodent Ulcer.
  • Locally invasive, meaning it destroys surrounding tissues.
  • Referred to as Tear Cancer, it occurs typically above a line drawn from the ear lobule to the corner of the mouth.
  • Originates from the basal layer of the epidermis.
  • The most common site is the nose, with the inner canthus being another frequent location.

Types
  • Nodular:
    • The most common type.
    • Appears as small, slow-growing pearly nodules.
    • Characterised by telangiectatic vessels on the surface.
    • Notable for a central depression called umbilication
    • It can also be pigmented.
  • Cystic
  • Superficial

Management
  • For non-aggressive tumours on the trunk or extremities, wide local excision with a 2 cm margin is usually sufficient.
  • For large, aggressive tumours affecting vital or cosmetic areas or recurrent tumours, Mohs micrographic surgery is recommended.

A female presented with a headache associated with photophobia and phonophobia. Which of the following drugs can be used for immediate relief?
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Acute Migraine

Prevention of Migraine
  • Pharmacologic Options:
    • Simple analgesics: Acetaminophen, aspirin, caffeine.
    • NSAIDs: Naproxen, ibuprofen, tolfenamic acid, diclofenac.
    • Triptans (5-HT1B/1D Agonists): Sumatriptan, rizatriptan, naratriptan, eletriptan, frovatriptan, zolmitriptan.
    • Gepants (CGRP Receptor Antagonists): Rimegepant, ubrogepant.
    • Ditans (5-HT1F Agonists): Lasmiditan.
    • Dopamine receptor antagonists: Metoclopramide, prochlorperazine.
    • Other options: Combination medications (e.g., acetaminophen, dichloralphenazone, isometheptene), opioids (limited use).
  • Non-Pharmacologic Management:
    • Identify and avoid triggers.
    • Regulated lifestyle: Healthy diet, regular exercise, consistent sleep, stress management (e.g., yoga, meditation).
    • Neuromodulation techniques: sTMS, nVNS.
  • Key Recommendations:
    • Use medications early in an attack.
    • If symptoms persist after 60 minutes, consider increasing the initial dose or switching drug classes.
    • Individualize treatment based on attack severity and patient response.
  • Indications for Preventive Treatment:
    • Consider patients with four or more migraine attacks per month or those unresponsive to abortive treatments.
  • Pharmacologic Options:
    • Beta Blockers: Propranolol (Option D ruled out), metoprolol.
    • Antidepressants: Amitriptyline, nortriptyline, venlafaxine.
    • Anticonvulsants: Topiramate (Option A ruled out), valproate.
    • CGRP Antagonists: Eptinezumab, erenumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab.
    • Other Medications: Flunarizine (Option B ruled out), candesartan, melatonin.
  • Considerations:
    • Preventive treatments often take 2–12 weeks to show effect.
    • Side effects vary; some medications require careful monitoring (e.g., weight gain with certain antidepressants).
    • Neuromodulation (sTMS) is also FDA-approved for prevention.
  • Patient Management:
    • Start with low doses and gradually increase.
    • Monitor effectiveness and side effects.
    • After stabilization, taper off medication after approximately six months to assess ongoing need.

A 10-month-old baby presented with hypsarrhythmia with salaam spells. The drug of choice is:
questions.explanation:
Epileptic spasm

(also called Infantile spasm, West syndrome or Hypsarrhythmia)

Definition

They typically occur in infants and are marked by sudden, forceful contractions of the muscles, particularly those of the trunk. The spasms often occur in clusters(5-50), especially upon waking, and are associated with widespread brain abnormalities.

Age Group

Predominantly occurs in infants, likely due to differences in neuronal function and connectivity in the immature CNS.

EEG Features

It shows hypsarrhythmia, which is marked by diffuse giant slow waves with a chaotic background of irregular, multifocal spikes and sharp waves.

Clinical Spasm EEG

During a spasm, the EEG shows significant background suppression, known as the "electrodecremental response."

EMG Characteristics

Reveals a rhomboid pattern, distinguishing it from brief tonic and myoclonic seizures.

Treatment

Occasional episodes:

  • Drug of choice: ACTH hormone +/- glucocorticoids

Associated with tuberous sclerosis (lifelong seizures):

  • Drug of choice: Vigabatrin

A female developed hyperprolactinemia and galactorrhea with recurrent episodes of nausea and vomiting. MRI shows pituitary adenoma. Her pregnancy test was negative. She did not give consent for surgery. Which drug should be used in management?
questions.explanation:
Prolactinomas

Explanation

  • Prolactinomas are typically microadenomas in pre-menopausal women, as the symptoms of elevated prolactin levels often lead to early diagnosis.
  • Prolactin levels correlate with the size of the tumour
  • Dopamine inhibits the production of prolactin.

Clinical Presentation
  • Prolactin has inhibitory effects on FSH & LH.
  • Women: Commonly present with amenorrhea, infertility, and galactorrhea. If the tumour extends beyond the sella, visual field defects & mass effects occur.
  • Men: Typically present with impotence, loss of libido, infertility, or signs of central nervous system (CNS) compression, such as headaches and visual disturbances.

Diagnosis
  • PRL levels > 200 μg/L most likely indicates prolactinoma
  • PRL levels below 100 μg/L may indicate microadenomas
  • MRI Head is recommended for all patients with hyperprolactinemia and it shows as a suprasellar mass.

Management

Dopamine Agonists

First-line treatment option

  • Cabergoline - long action and better tolerance
    • Galactorrhea improves in 90% of patients
    • PRL levels are normal in 80% of patients with microadenomas and 70% with macroprolactinomas.
  • Bromocriptine
    • Shorter action - preferable in women wishing to conceive

Side effects may include nausea, mental fogging, nightmares, insomnia, vertigo and postural hypotension

Surgery

Indication

  • Tumor causing pituitary apoplexy.
  • Cases resistant to medical therapy.
  • Invasive macroadenomas affecting vision.
  • Pregnant woman with clinical features of tumor.
  • Mass effect of tumor persisting > 1 month with medical therapy.

Radiotherapy

Reserved for aggressive tumors that do not respond to dopamine agonists or surgery.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of death in a body with a horizontal ligature mark completely encircling the neck and located below the thyroid, with no dribbling of saliva?
questions.explanation:
Finding

Description
Face
  • Congested, swollen, and cyanosed.
  • Tardieu's spots (petechiae) on the forehead, temples, eyelids, and conjunctiva.
  • Prominent eyes with congested conjunctiva, dilated pupils, and possible subconjunctival haemorrhages.
  • Cyanosis of lips, fingernails, and earlobes.
  • Postmortem staining above the ligature.
  • Swollen, dark-coloured, protruding tongue, possibly bitten.
  • Bloodstained frothy fluid and mucus in mouth and nostrils.
Neck
  • Ligature mark ('furrow'): well-defined groove, typically the same width as the ligature, often horizontal.
  • More prominent on the front and sides of the neck.
  • Red base with congested or ecchymosed margins; imprint pattern may be present.
  • Can be indistinct if the ligature is soft; it may appear as a deep groove with a narrow cord ('cheese cutter method').
  • May show an oblique appearance if the victim was dragged post-strangulation.
Other Body Parts
  • Deep, prominent postmortem staining.
  • Involuntary discharge of urine and faecal matter; less common seminal ejaculation.
  • Clenched hands; possible genital turgidity.
  • Possible abrasions, fingernail marks, and contusions on face, and arms, indicating struggle.
  • Horizontal, irregular abrasions on the neck may indicate attempts to remove ligature.

Hanging

Strangulation

Face

questions.explanation:
BNS Section

Offense

BNS Section 269

 
  • This section pertains to negligent acts that are likely to spread infection of a disease dangerous to life.
  • The punishment can be imprisonment for up to six months or a fine or both.

BNS Section 272

 
  • This section deals with malignant acts likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life.
  • The punishment can be imprisonment for up to two years or fine.

BNS Section 106

 
  • This section deals with causing death by negligence.
  • It applies when death is caused by a rash or negligent act that does not amount to culpable homicide.
  • The punishment for such an offense is imprisonment for up to two years, or a fine, or both.

BNS Section 109

 
  • This section pertains to attempt to murder.
  • The punishment can extend to imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of up to 10 years and a fine.

Feature

Civil Negligence

Criminal Negligence

Offense

No specific and clear violation of law

Must have specifically violated a particular criminal law

Negligence

Gross negligence, inattention, or lack of competence

Civil court

Guilt must be proved beyond reasonable doubt

Punishment

Defense for doctor

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis for a 16-year-old girl who experiences strong food cravings and engages in excessive eating followed by self-induced vomiting?

Correct Answer B - Bulimia nervosa

Features of Bulimia nervosa

Binge Eating Episodes

Recurring episodes of binge eating, occurring at least weekly for the last 3 months.

Compensatory Behaviors

Purging behaviours (self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics), excessive exercise, fasting.

BMI

Often normal or slightly overweight (compared to anorexia nervosa).

Gender prevalence

More common in females than males

Physical Signs
  • Parotid gland hypertrophy (may see increased serum amylase)
  • Enamel erosion (from vomiting)
  • Mallory-Weiss syndrome (esophageal tears)
  • These signs appear due to repeated purging.

Electrolyte Disturbances

Commonly, hypokalemia and hypochloremia.

Metabolic Changes

Metabolic alkalosis due to vomiting.

Physical Findings

Dorsal hand calluses from induced vomiting (Russell sign).

Treatment for Bulimia Nervosa

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)

This is the first-line treatment, focusing on modifying distorted thoughts and behaviours related to eating and body image.

Nutritional Rehabilitation

It is aimed at restoring healthy eating patterns and addressing nutritional deficiencies

Antidepressants
  • Fluoxetine
  • Topiramate
  • Bupropion

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a woman who is 4 days postpartum and experiencing tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia?

Postpartum Depression

(Option A)

(Option C)

Occurrence

Affects up to 80% of women after childbirth
  • Affects 10- 15% of women
  • 70% risk of recurrence in next pregnancy
  • Incidence is about 1-2 in 1000 deliveries
  • 50% risk of recurrence in next pregnancy

Timing

Onset 3-5 days postpartum, resolves by days to weeks

Within the first 6 weeks postpartum or after abortion

Symptoms appear within 2-3 weeks postpartum and last 2-3 months

Transient symptoms such as

  • Loss of appetite
  • Insomnia
  • Social withdrawal
  • Irritability

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. Investigations show leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Sarcoidosis is a chronic multisystem inflammatory disorder of unknown cause, characterized by the accumulation of T lymphocytes and mononuclear phagocytes, leading to the formation of non-caseating granulomas in various tissues of the body.

Clinical Presentation

Lungs (90%)

  • Interstitial lung disease
  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Cavitation (Rare)
  • Pleural involvement (1-5% cases) with occasional pleural effusion

Pulmonary Symptoms: Dry cough, dyspnea, chest pain

 

Lymph Nodes (75-90%)

  • Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (hallmark)
  • Parotid enlargement

 

Extrapulmonary Symptoms:

  • Skin
    • Erythema nodosum (tender red nodules, often on shins)

 

    • Lupus pernio (purple-blue shiny lesions on nose, cheeks, lips, and ears)
  • Eyes: Anterior Uveitis
  • Kidneys: Hypercalcemia with or without hypercalciuria
  • Nervous System: Facial nerve palsy, Peripheral neuropathy
  • Heart: Cor pulmonale (secondary to pulmonary fibrosis)

Constitutional Symptoms: Fever, fatigue, night sweats, weight loss

Syndromes Associated

 
  • Lofgren's syndrome: Features include erythema nodosum (painful red nodules on the shins), hilar lymphadenopathy, and periarticular arthritis.
  • Mikulicz syndrome: Involves bilateral enlargement of the parotid, submaxillary, and sublingual glands.

Histopathological Features
  • Presence of non-caseating granulomas in affected organs
  • Granulomas are often composed of epithelioid histiocytes and giant cells (Langerhans or foreign body type)

 

Inclusion Bodies in Giant Cells:

  • Schaumann bodies (calcium-protein inclusions)

 

  • Asteroid bodies (stellate-shaped inclusions)

Initial Diagnostic Workup

History and Physical Examination

  • Assess for respiratory symptoms and extrapulmonary signs
  • Check for bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and skin lesions

Chest Imaging

  • Chest X-ray (Stage 1: bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is a hallmark finding)

Laboratory Investigations

Serum Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE)

  • Elevated in 60% of cases (non-specific but supportive)

Calcium Levels

  • Hypercalcemia due to increased 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D production by macrophages in granulomas

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL)

  • CD4/CD8 ratio > 3.5 supports sarcoidosis (not diagnostic alone)

Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs)
  • Restrictive Pattern
  • Decreased FVC and TLC
  • Normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio
  • Decreased DLCO (diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide)

Imaging Studies

Chest X-Ray: Staging based on lung involvement

Stage 0

Normal

Stage 1

Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy

Stage 2

Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with pulmonary infiltrates

Stage 3

Pulmonary infiltrates only

Stage 4

Pulmonary fibrosis

High-Resolution CT (HRCT):

  • Ground-glass opacities
  • Perilymphatic nodules
  • Fibrotic changes

Histopathology

Tissue Biopsy (Gold Standard)

  • Non-caseating granulomas in lung, lymph nodes, or skin
  • Exclusion of other granulomatous diseases such as tuberculosis (caseating granulomas) and fungal infections

Other Diagnostic Tests

Gallium-67 Scintigraphy

  • Panda Sign: Uptake in lacrimal and parotid glands

 

  • Lambda Sign: Uptake in bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes

 

 

Positron Emission Tomography (PET)

  • Identifies active inflammation and organ involvement

Differential Diagnosis
  • Infections: Tuberculosis, fungal infections
  • Autoimmune Disorders: Lupus, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Malignancies: Lymphoma, metastatic carcinoma

Diagnostic Criteria
  • Compatible clinical and radiographic presentation
  • Non-caseating granulomas on histopathology
  • Exclusion of other granulomatous diseases

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration. A CT scan was done, which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page: 1011, 1012, 2200.
  • ↳ Typical Bacterial Pneumonia - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
  • ↳ Lobar pneumonia | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org

Investigation

Findings

Initial Evaluation
  • Clinical suspicion based on patient history and physical examination.

Chest Radiography
  • The most important initial test for pneumonia diagnosis.
  • Shows pulmonary infiltrate; indicates type (lobar, interstitial, unilateral, or bilateral).
  • Cannot reliably differentiate between bacterial and non-bacterial causes.

CT Scan
  • More accurate than a chest X-ray.
  • Focal dense opacification of an entire lobe occurs, with relative sparing of the large airways. Associated findings may include ground-glass opacities in a lobar or segmental pattern, indicating areas of partial involvement or atelectasis.
  • Image shows left upper lung lobe consolidation of heterogenous density, with multiple air bronchograms, and small left pleural effusion

Laboratory Tests
  • Complete Blood Count (CBC):
    • Look for leukocytosis (leftward shift) as a sign of infection.
    • Leukopenia may indicate a poor prognosis.
  • Inflammatory Biomarkers: ESR and acute phase reactants to assess severity.

Sputum Analysis
  • Sputum Gram stain and culture critical for suspected lobar pneumonia.
  • Sputum culture is the most specific diagnostic test for identifying the causative organism.

Influenza Testing
  • Recommended during winter months due to the risk of co-infection with pneumonia.

Patient Stratification
  • Use CURB-65 and the pneumonia severity index to determine hospitalization needs.

Additional Testing
  • Hospitalized patients: sputum culture, blood culture, and/or urine antigen testing before antibiotics.

Invasive Procedures
  • Thoracocentesis, bronchoscopy, pleural biopsy, and pleural fluid culture are rarely performed.
  • Open lung biopsy is the ultimate specific diagnostic test.

questions.text: A female patient with a negative urine pregnancy test presents to you with galactorrhea. An MRI was done, which revealed a large pituitary tumor. If the patient is not willing to undergo surgery, which of the following is the best drug for treatment?
questions.explanation:
Cause

Mostly idiopathic; can be associated with MEN 1 or RET gene mutations.

Classification

Microadenomas: <1 cm, often asymptomatic.

Macroadenomas: >1 cm, may cause visual field defects, headaches, and neurological symptoms.

Symptoms

Galactorrhea, amenorrhea, infertility (women)

Erectile dysfunction, reduced libido (men)

Headaches, visual disturbances (e.g., bitemporal hemianopia, diplopia in large tumors).

Diagnosis

Elevated prolactin levels, MRI for tumor imaging.

Treatment

Dopamine agonists: Bromocriptine, Cabergoline (first-line) to reduce prolactin secretion and tumor size.

Cabergoline: Preferred; fewer side effects.

Surgical: If resistant to or intolerant of dopamine agonists, or with significant complications.

Radiotherapy: For resistant cases.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with an irregularly irregular pulse of 120/minute and a pulse deficit of 20. Which of the following would be the jugular venous pressure (JVP) finding?
questions.explanation:
Atrial Fibrillation

Features
  • Characterized by abnormal automatic firing and multiple re-entry circuits.
  • Atria beat rapidly and ineffectively; ventricles activated irregularly
  • Produces an "irregularly irregular" pulse
  • Palpitations, syncope, and breathlessness can be present
  • Asymptomatic AF: Can present as systemic embolism and stroke

ECG Features
  • QRS Complexes: Irregular but normal
  • P Waves: Absent; baseline may show irregular fibrillation waves
  • Ventricular Rate:
    • Fast at onset (120-160 beats/min)
    • Slower in chronic AF due to medication effects and AV nodal fatigue

JVP

Absent a wave

Management

Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation

  • First-line Therapy: Beta-blockers are effective in patients with CAD, hypertension, and heart failure.
  • Class Ic Drugs: Propafenone or flecainide to prevent episodes (not for patients with CAD or LV dysfunction).
  • Class III Drugs:
    • Amiodarone: Most effective but with significant side effects; used when other treatments fail.
    • Dronedarone: Alternative to amiodarone; contraindicated in heart failure.
  • Rate Control: Digoxin and verapamil for AV node conduction slowing, but not for AF prevention.
  • Catheter Ablation: Considered for patients with drug-resistant AF; prevents AF in ~75% of cases but may have complications.

Persistent Atrial Fibrillation

  • Rhythm Control:
    • Cardioversion: Electrical or pharmacological (e.g., intravenous flecainide or amiodarone).
    • Timing: Immediate if AF <48 hours; anticoagulation required if AF ≥48 hours.
    • Prophylactic Amiodarone: To reduce recurrence risk.
  • Rate Control:
    • Medications: Digoxin, β-blockers, or rate-limiting calcium antagonists (verapamil, diltiazem).
    • Combination Therapy: Digoxin with β-blockers; avoid combining calcium antagonists with β-blockers.
    • Pace and Ablate: Permanent pacemaker with AV nodal block for symptomatic AF.

Thromboprophylaxis

  • Anticoagulation: Required for stroke prevention due to blood stasis in the left atrium.
    • Warfarin: INR target of 2.0–3.0; start 4 weeks prior to cardioversion.
    • DOACs: Rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban, and dabigatran as alternatives to warfarin; no monitoring needed.
  • Risk Assessment:
    • CHA2DS2-VASc Score: For stroke risk; anticoagulate if score ≥2.
    • HAS-BLED Score: For bleeding risk; monitor patients with score ≥3.
  • Aspirin: Not recommended due to low efficacy in preventing embolic stroke.

CHA2DS2-VASc stroke risk scoring system for AF

Points

Parameters

Score

C

1

1

A2

1

questions.text: Identify the type of hymen shown in the image below.
questions.explanation:
Hymen Type

Clinical Presentation

Treatment

Imperforate (Option A)
  • Menarche with cyclic pain, and amenorrhea.
  • Abdominal pain.
  • Cryptomenorrhea: Menstrual blood is produced but not expelled from the body.
  • Hematocolpos: Bulging, bluish membrane at the introitus.
  • Hematometra: Accumulation of menstrual blood in the uterus.
  • Hematosalpinx: Accumulation of blood in the fallopian tubes.
  • Differential Diagnosis: Transverse Vaginal septum -
    • Incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts and urogenital sinus.
    • A fibrous band of tissue at various levels (low, mid, or high) that divides the vagina horizontally.
    • Normal external genitalia; vaginal examination reveals a membrane or band within the vagina on palpation.
    • Mx: Surgical resection of the septum.
  • Incision and drainage.
  • Avoid needle aspiration, as this can lead to infection.

Microperforate

Very small opening, which may cause menstrual irregularities or difficulty with tampon use.

Surgical incision followed by excision of the hymen.

Septate

 
  • Band of tissue dividing the vaginal opening
  • Dyspareunia.
  • If one side of a septate vagina is obstructed, it can lead to mucocolpos or hematocolpos.

Excision.

Cribriform (sieve)

Multiple small openings allow for menstrual flow but often cause discomfort or difficulties with intercourse.

 

Annular (Option D)
  • Menstrual irregularities.
  • Difficulty in tampon placement/ intercourse.

 

Naviculare (boatlike)

Semilunar/ Crescentric (Option B)

  • Crescent-shaped opening, with tissue along the lower portion of the vaginal opening, leaving a large central opening.
  • Seen in Childhood/Adolescence.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with abdominal distension, jaundice, and pruritis. Ascitic fluid analysis revealed a neutrophil count of 650 per cubic mm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Description

A severe complication of ascites, characterised by spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intra-abdominal source.

Causative organism
  • Escherichia coli (most common) and other gut bacteria.
  • Gram-positive bacteria (Streptococcus viridans, Staphylococcus aureus, and Enterococcus)

Source of infection

Clinical features
  • Worsening of ascites
  • Fever, nausea, vomiting
  • Increase in abdominal girth
  • Encephalopathy

Diagnosis

Ascitic fluid analysis shows:

  • Turbid appearance

 

  • Neutrophil count >250/μL
  • Culture and gram satins reveal the causative organisms

Management

IV 3rd generation cephalosporins (cefotaxime) for 5 days

Prevention

  • Paracentesis within 12 hours of hospital admission
  • Norfloxacin administration (cirrhotic patients with an episode of SBP)
  • Quinolone antibiotic prophylaxis (recurrent episodes of SBP in variceal bleeding).

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman is evaluated for primary infertility. Hysterosalpingography was done and reveals the findings shown below. What is the anomaly seen in the image?
questions.explanation:
Müllerian Uterine Anomaly

Description

Clinical Presentation

Treatment

Septate Uterus

Incomplete resorption of the septum between the Müllerian ducts, resulting in a fibrous septum within the uterine cavity.

Recurrent first-trimester miscarriages, Infertility.

  • DD: Bicornuate uterus has an intercomual angle >105 degrees during hysterosalpingography.

Hysteroscopic metroplasty to remove the septum.

Bicornuate Uterus (Option C)

Incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts, leading to a heart-shaped uterus with two cavities.

Higher incidence of infertility, endometriosis, and dysmenorrhea.

  • Requires 3D USG/ MRI to differentiate from Septate Uterus

Metroplasty in severe cases. Often managed conservatively.

Didelphys Uterus (Option B)

Complete non-fusion of the Müllerian ducts, two separate uteri, and often two cervices.

Preterm labor, Menstrual irregularities.

Managed conservatively, Metroplasty if symptomatic.

Unicornuate Uterus - Noncommunicating

(Option D)

Partial development of one Müllerian duct, resulting in a single-horned uterus.

Cyclic pelvic pain may be misdiagnosed as an adnexal mass.

Ectopic pregnancy, Preterm labor

Prophylactic cerclage placement or progesterone supplementation to prevent preterm birth.

Arcuate Uterus

Mild indentation at the top of the uterine cavity due to minor incomplete resorption of the septum.

Generally asymptomatic and normal reproductive outcomes.

Reassurance and conservative management.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with no other comorbid conditions develops preeclampsia. She enquires about the cause of her condition. The doctor explains that it is due to the failure of the invasion of:
questions.correct_answer: C. Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts
questions.explanation:
Feature

Normal Pregnancy

Pregnancy-Induced Hypertension (PIH)

Placentation
  • Extravillous trophoblasts invade the spiral arteries of the uterus around week 20.
  • This invasion widens the spiral arteries.
  • The widening enhances blood flow to the placenta.
  • This is known as secondary placentation.
  • Incomplete invasion of the spiral arteries by extravillous trophoblasts.
  • Persistent narrow vessels with reduced blood flow and placental ischemia.

Immune Response

T-helper 2 cells dominate, promoting humoral immunity and tolerance of the fetal antigens.
  • A shift towards T-helper 1 cell activity.
  • Increasing the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, γ-interferon, IL-2).
  • Contributing to endothelial dysfunction.

Endothelial Function

Maintains normal vascular tone and permeability, regulating blood flow and preventing inappropriate clotting.

Endothelial cells become dysfunctional, leading to vasoconstriction, increased permeability (edema), and activation of the coagulation cascade.

Angiogenic Balance
  • Pro-angiogenic factors (VEGF, PlGF, TGF-β) promote blood vessel growth.
  • Anti-angiogenic factors (sFlt-1, sEng) inhibit blood vessel growth.
  • A balance between these factors is essential for proper placental development and function.
  • Imbalance occurs with elevated production of anti-angiogenic factors (sFlt-1, sEng).
  • Reduced levels of pro-angiogenic factors are observed.
  • sFlt-1 binds to and deactivates VEGF and PlGF.
  • sEng inhibits TGF-β signaling.
  • This imbalance leads to endothelial dysfunction and impaired angiogenesis

Blood Pressure

Blood pressure remains within the normal range due to the vasodilatory effects of pregnancy hormones
  • Hypertension occurs after 20 weeks of pregnancy, characterized by blood pressure over 140/90 mmHg.
  • It results from vasoconstriction, endothelial dysfunction, and heightened sensitivity to vasopressors.

questions.text: A woman with an obstetric score of G2P1 comes to the clinic at 14 weeks of gestation for her antenatal checkup. A uterine artery Doppler was suggested by the doctor. What would it detect?
A patient underwent a cystoscopy, which showed multiple yellow-white plaques in the trigone of the bladder. The histopathology image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Malakoplakia

Malakoplakia

Common Pathogen

Escherichia coli (most common), other Gram-negative bacteria

Histopathology

Von Hansemann cells (large, foamy histiocytes) with Michaelis-Gutmann bodies (PAS-positive inclusions).

Characteristic Inclusions

Michaelis-Gutmann bodies (basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions)

Staining

Positive staining with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS), von Kossa, and Perl’s stains

Associated Conditions

Immunocompromised states, such as organ transplantation, HIV, diabetes, malignancy

Organ Involvement

Predominantly genitourinary tract, but can affect multiple organ systems

Treatment

Antibiotics (fluoroquinolones, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), possible surgical excision

Prognosis

Requires treatment; may lead to complications if untreated; variable course with potential relapses.

(Option D)

Mechanism
  • Increased breakdown of red blood cells
  • Excessive bilirubin production

  • Blocked bile flow
  • Accumulation of conjugated bilirubin in bloodstream

Clinical Features
  • Yellowing of skin and sclera
  • Anemia
  • Fatigue
  • Splenomegaly
  • Yellowing of skin and sclera
  • Fatigue

Elevated unconjugated and conjugated (direct) bilirubin

Elevated conjugated (direct) bilirubin

  • ALP: Normal
  • GGT: Normal

  • ALP: Elevated

  • ALP: Markedly elevated

Prolonged PT

Prolonged PT

questions.text: While conducting a delivery, you perform the maneuver shown below. Following this, there is incomplete separation of the placenta and massive hemorrhage. What is your next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Start oxytocin infusion and wait for spontaneous delivery of the placenta

options.label: C
options.text: Arrange for blood and use Crede's method for placental delivery

questions.explanation:
Causes of Primary PPH

Cause

Description

Factors increasing risk

Uterine Atony (Most common)

The inability of the uterus to contract effectively after delivery leads to a soft and boggy uterus and continuous bleeding from the placental site.
  • Grand multiparity
  • Overdistension of the uterus: Multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, large baby Malnutrition, and anemia
  • Antepartum hemorrhage: Placenta previa and placental abruption
  • Prolonged labour
  • Anesthesia
  • Oxytocin use
  • Uterine malformations
  • Other factors: Obesity, h/o PPH, advanced maternal age (over 40 years), tocolytics and magnesium sulfate

Retained Tissue

Prevents proper uterine contraction, causing primary PPH with continued bleeding and incomplete contraction.

Although more commonly associated with secondary PPH, retained placental fragments can also be a cause of primary PPH.

Trauma to the genital tract

Cervical, vaginal, or perineal tears are a significant cause of primary PPH. This type of bleeding occurs despite a well-contracted uterus.
  • Assisted deliveries
  • Rapid labor
  • Large babies

 

Thrombin (Coagulopathy)

Involves disorders of blood clotting, which are a less common cause of PPH. They can be acquired or congenital.
  • Placental abruption
  • Jaundice in pregnancy
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Severe pre-eclampsia
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Intrauterine device (IUD)

Aspect

Traumatic Postpartum Hemorrhage

Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage

Cause

Trauma to the genital tract (e.g., cervix, vagina, perineum, episiotomy, uterine rupture, hematomas)

Inadequate uterine contraction and retraction after placenta separation

Prevalence

20% of cases of postpartum hemorrhage

80% of cases of postpartum hemorrhage

Common Risk Factors

Operative delivery (forceps, vacuum), episiotomy, cesarean section, rapid labor

Grand multiparity, overdistension of uterus, anemia, uterine malformations

Uterus Condition

Uterus is well contracted despite bleeding

Uterus is flabby, not contracting properly

Management

Repair of lacerations, removal of hematomas, and possible surgical intervention

Uterine massage, oxytocin infusion, bimanual compression, surgical intervention if necessary

Blood Loss Control

Bleeding is from injured vessels (episiotomy, ruptured uterus, etc.)

Bleeding is from uncompressed uterine sinuses due to lack of contraction

Associated Complications

Hematomas, uterine rupture, infection, blood loss from surgical wounds

Shock, anemia, uterine infections, DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation)

questions.text: Which of the following measures is associated with an increased life span?

options.label: D
options.text: Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors

questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Decreasing calorie intake by 30%

Insulin and IGF-1 Signaling

IGF-1, produced in response to growth hormone, mimics insulin signalling, promoting an anabolic state, cell growth, and replication.

Sirtuins
  • These are NAD-dependent deacetylases that help adapt to stressors like food deprivation and DNA damage.
  • They promote longevity by regulating genes that reduce metabolic activity, apoptosis, and oxidative damage.
  • Sirtuins also improve insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism.

questions.text: A woman presents with fever, arthralgia, ulcers, fatigue for the past six months, and new-onset hematuria. Urine examination reveals RBC casts and proteinuria. What is the likely diagnosis?
A female patient collapses soon after delivery. There is profuse bleeding and features of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Which of the following is the most likely etiology?
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Pathophysiology
  • Amniotic fluid or fetal debris enters the maternal circulation, triggering a systemic inflammatory response.
  • Leads to cardiorespiratory collapse and coagulopathy (DIC).

Presentation
  • Sudden onset of hypotension or cardiac arrest.
  • Respiratory distress and gasping for air.
  • Profuse bleeding due to coagulopathy/DIC.
  • Potential seizures or altered consciousness.

Timing

Most cases occur during labor, immediately postpartum, or within 30 minutes of delivery.

Clinical Triad
  • Hemodynamic collapse.
  • Respiratory compromise.
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 40 weeks of gestation with lower abdominal pain. She has been in labor for 3 hours. Which of the following will determine if she is in active labor?

options.label: C
options.text: More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement

questions.correct_answer: C. More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement
questions.explanation:
Stage

Definition

Features

Contractions

First Stage

Onset of labor to full cervical dilatation (10 cm).

 

  • Latent Phase: Early cervical changes with slower progress.
  • Active Phase: Faster cervical dilatation (≥5 cm) with regular contractions.
  • Cervical dilatation and effacement occur.
  • Intermittent painful uterine contractions.
  • "Show" (blood-stained mucus) is common.
  • Active labor starts at cervical dilatation ≥5 cm with regular contractions.

Latent Phase: Irregular and mild.

Active Phase: Regular; 3–5 min apart, lasting ~45 seconds.

Second Stage

From complete cervical dilatation (10 cm) to fetal delivery.
  • Begins after complete cervical dilation.
  • Ends with the delivery of the baby.

Strong and frequent; 2–3 minutes apart.

Third Stage

From fetal delivery to placental expulsion.
  • Placental separation and expulsion occur.
  • Average duration: 5–15 minutes.

Mild uterine contractions to aid placental expulsion.

Fourth Stage

Observation for at least 1 hour after placental expulsion.
  • Monitoring for postpartum hemorrhage and uterine contraction.

Uterine contractions continue, aiding hemostasis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with dragging pain in the abdomen. On examination, there is a massive splenomegaly. A peripheral smear shows leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and basophils. Which of the following translocations is seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - t(9;22)

CML

Genetics

Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22))

Origin

Myeloid lineage

Etiopathogenesis
  • BCR-ABL fusion gene due to t(9;22) causes increased tyrosine kinase activity.
  • Radiation exposure.

Clinical features
  • Occurs in adults.
  • Often presents with splenomegaly, fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and abdominal discomfort.
  • It can progress to a blast crisis with features of acute leukemia.

Diagnosis
  • Bone marrow aspirate to confirm diagnosis
  • Peripheral smear: shows many mature neutrophils, some metamyelocytes, and myelocytes.
  • On FISH - the presence of BCR ABL fusion gene product can be seen.

Management

Tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as Imatinib.
